node.text:
We had the incredible honor of speaking with the new Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona (@seccardona) about the Administration’s vision for kids and families, especially as it relates to equity. We discuss the American Families Plan and how it will invest in and support access to child-care, preschool, higher education and more.

We talk about the critical role HBCUs play in our country and why the @whitehouse is investing $39 billion into subsidizing tuition for students who attend them, the importance of investing into a more diverse teacher pipeline, and why access to free high-quality preschool and free community college matters.

Dr. Cardona is a father and lifelong educator with over 2 decades of experience as a public school educator. We hope you enjoy this conversation and stay tuned in to the work he'll be doing as Secretary of Education.

Please check out the link in our bio or Stories to learn more.

#TeachersOfInstagram #HBCU #Education

node.title: Special conversation with Secretary of Education Dr. Miguel Cardona

node.text:
Cleo Wade's debut and NYTimes best-selling picture book, What The Road Said, is not only a must-read, it is a comforting, wisdom-filled, and uplifting guide for kids to look to as they navigate their own journeys in life. We know it’s one kids will look to and revisit often for reassurance and guidance. It’s so valuable for all ages and stages of life and one that readers will be lifted up by through its encouraging and nurturing words. Reading this book feels like sitting down with a trusted and loving friend. 

We hope you enjoy this conversation about the book with @jennifer.garner as part of our @onceuponafarm Storyteller series. We also have 10 signed copies of What The Road Said to giveaway—please comment below if we can send you one.

node.text:
Talks to us about @virulenthate's newest report analyzing anti-Asian racism in 2020. The Virulent Hate Project identifies, analyzes, and maps incidents of anti-Asian harassment, violence, discrimination, and stigmatization, and researches trends in anti-Asian racism and Asian American activism. 

Their new report released this week examined over 4,337 pieces of news media on anti-Asian racism and found that of the incidents where the race of the perpetrator is known, they are predominantly male and disproportionately white. This is significant because the videos being centered and receiving mass circulation in the media and on social media have been creating a misconception that the majority of perpetrators are Black.

Dr. Borja speaks with us about the key findings of the new report, the ongoing trope of Black/Asian conflict and why it's important for us to think critically about how we may be reproducing that harmful narrative, how Black and Asian communities have been working in solidarity in response to anti-Asian racism, and how we can continue to show solidarity in the future and support our communities.

Special thanks to Dr. Borja for her time and for sharing her work and expertise with us! Please be sure to stay tuned for her next report on Asian American activism.

For more information, visit virulenthate.org. Dr. Borja is on IG and Twitter at @melissamayborja

node.title: Dr. Melissa May Borja, lead of the Virulent Hate Project

node.text:
Repost from @wongfupro
•
If you didn't know, May is Asian Pacific American Heritage Month. Although we're bringing attention to this in May, we hope the message will continue to resonate + be heard moving forward. Let’s keep on educating, speaking out, and uplifting. #StopAsianHate #APAHM

For more verified donation pages and organization fundraisers visit:
https://www.gofundme.com/c/act/stop-aapi-hate

node.title: PSA from our Asian Creator Community by @wongfupro via @goldhouseco

node.text:
We partnered with @harryshumjr and @wongfupro to bring you a storytime playlist celebrating AAPI voices and experiences. Today, we are so excited to share the first read-aloud video with you!

Harry will be reading Grandpa Grumps by @katrinamoore1011 and @xindiyanart, published by @littlebeebooks. Please check it out now on the YouTube Kids app and our YouTube channel (linked in our Stories). 

We hope you love it and share it with your kids and students. Please stay tuned for new read-alouds each week this month featuring @padmalakshmi, @mingna_wen and Randall Park!

#AAPIStorytime #ReadAloud #AsianAmerican #AAPI #StopAsianHate

node.title: AAPI Storytime featuring Harry Shum Jr.

node.text: I Am Smart, I Am Blessed, I Can Do ANYTHING! In this special episode of #Storytellers, @jennifer.garner chats with @ayaandiop, the kid whose positive energy landed him a viral video of his walk to school, and inspired his mom, @alissa360style, and aunt, @AMomDotCom to write @ImSmartImBlessedICanDoAnything - a children's book that shows the importance of affirmations at any age. As @jennifer.garner reminds us, “All of us can benefit from taking a look at how we talk to ourselves.”

node.text:
From @tiffanyhaddish:
•
I was Working today for @kidssaythedarndestthings
Airing very soon on @cbstv . The Producers decided to tell me I WON a Grammy while I was interviewing these two young ladies Lauren and Ava, that want to someday be president of the United States of America. I was flooded with a such a since of accomplishment and relief. I kinda didn’t know what to say. I just wanted to cry but I knew it would have confused the babies. So I decided to use that moment to teach and share my feelings. Thank you @recordingacademy  for the honor. Thank you to everyone that made #blackmitzvah happen @pushitproductions @pagehurwitz #wandasykes #netflix #JackieKnobbe #Dionnewynn #yvettesheldon #LawRoach #jerrodcarmichael #lilrelhowery #chrisspencer #shereadyproductions #SHEREADY

node.text: It is our absolute privilege to host @SecondGentleman Douglas Emhoff in this very special story time. In celebration of Read Across America Day and Women's History Month, Mr. Emhoff is reading the book I Dissent: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Makes Her Mark by Debbie Levy and Elizabeth Baddeley. We hope you love it as much as we do! @simonkids

node.title: National Read Across America Day with Douglas Emhoff

node.text:
We are so excited to feature @meena in conversation with @jennifer.garner for this month’s @onceuponafarm Storytellers! 

Meena’s newest book, Ambitious Girl, is out tomorrow! It is an affirmation to young girls that they can do and be anything. It’s message of owning and living your purpose, not letting anyone tell you who you are, and being unapologetic about taking up space (in a world that too often tells Black girls and girls of color that they are “too loud” “too much”, and “too confident”) is deeply needed and important. 

In addition to Ambitious Girl, Meena also talks about her first book, Kamala and Maya’s Big Idea, and its message that no matter how small, each of us can make an impact. 

Please be sure to check out Meena’s movement and the incredible work she does in support of social and racial justice organizations with @phenomenal. Visit our Stories for the Once Upon A Farm blog post with links to Meena’s website and books.

We are so excited to host Jingle Jangle producer, @lynsissontalbert, as she reads aloud her picture book, The Square Root of Possible, based on the beautiful new @netflix holiday film. The book is co-authored by Jingle Jangle writer/director, @davidetalbert. 

Be sure to also check out the middle-grade book they co-wrote, called Jingle Jangle: The Invention of Jeronicus Jangle, for ages 8-12. 

Special thanks to Lyn and @penguinkids for this wonderful storytime. We appreciate you tuning in and wish you happy holidays!

node.text:
“Representation matters. Holocaust denial and antisemitic incidents are at an all-time high, and stories sharing these painful truths are necessary. But we need representation extending beyond the holidays, food, and historical traumas that are so often centered in Jewish stories. We need casual, playful representation, too. Stories that celebrate everyday resilience… joy! For me, it’s joy that stands out as a critical antidote to rising antisemitism.

I hope that young readers delight in Kvetch’s Yiddish integrated throughout the text! I hope they get curious about Gitty’s name spelled in Hebrew alongside a Magen David proudly displayed on her bedroom wall. And I hope they recognize something universal— maybe even themselves!—in glass-half-full Gitty and curmudgeonly Kvetch. It's the jubilant affirmation of Jewish identity in all its forms that will elevate our shared humanity above all else. In its own small way, I hope that a story like Gitty and Kvetch can offer a joyful, humanizing counter-narrative for Jewish and non-Jewish kids alike.” - Author Caroline Kusin Pritchard

Gitty and Kvetch is a hilariously sweet story about an opposites-attract friendship. Gitty always sees the bright side of life, while her Yiddish-slinging, feathered friend Kvetch is always, well, kvetching about the trouble they get into. One perfect day, Gitty ropes Kvetch into shlepping off on a new adventure to their perfect purple treehouse. But when her perfect surprise goes awry, oy vey, suddenly it’s Gitty who’s kvetching. Can Kvetch come out of his funk to lift Gitty’s spirits back up?

Jewish people represent less than 2% of the U.S. population but nearly 60% of all religiously motivated hate crimes. Representation is key, and stories like this one are deeply important and needed. This joy-filled and adorable story by @carolinepritchardwrites, illustrated by @ariellandyart is out and available now from @simonkids. Ages 4-8. Mark your calendars for the online book launch event and reading on 9/23 at 4 pm PT. Facebook.com/interabangbooks

node.text:
We are honored to reveal the trailer for Loujain Dreams of Sunflowers, a picture book celebrating the incredible story of Saudi women’s rights activist @loujainhathloul. Co-written by Loujain’s sister @linaalhathloul and women’s human rights activist @umamishranewbery, @loujaindreamsofsunflowers tells an unforgettable girl-power story of gender equality and a family that takes a stand against their own country’s unjust treatment of girls. 

Loujain AlHathloul was imprisoned for 1001 days for fighting for women’s right to drive in Saudi Arabia. Loujain was released from prison in February 2021 but remains under heavy restrictions and is still fighting for justice. 

“We wrote Loujain Dreams of Sunflowers to celebrate the brave activism of Lina’s sister, who is a hero to so many women around the world. The story of Loujain and the many international women’s rights activists who have fought for our rights at such a high cost should be better known. We need to lift up those who sacrifice to bring about change. This book is a tribute to Loujain and all girls who dream of the impossible.” - Lina and Uma

Beautifully illustrated by New York Times bestselling artist @rebeccagreenillustration, Loujain Dreams of Sunflowers lovingly showcases a courageous girl who dreams of flying to see an enormous field of sunflowers. Despite her classmates’ taunts that only boys are allowed to fly, she’s determined: Only by flying can she see the color-filled field of sunflowers her baba has described and she longs to see. Take a peek via this trailer from three-time Emmy Award winning production company @saltproject.

To be released February 8, 2022 from @mineditionus

node.text:
Cover Reveal!! ✨

We are so excited to share the cover, and a sneak peak of some of the interior pages, for this forthcoming picture book from @leahs_mark and @e.b._lewis! 

Daddy Speaks Love is a moving tribute to the joy and grounding that fathers bring to their children’s lives. 

From day one, a daddy speaks love to his little one. And along with that love, his words and actions speak truth, joy, comfort, and pride. He answers a million questions and sets an example for the future, speaking out for equality and justice, while sharing lessons from the past. But most of all, daddies encourage their young ones to fight for a better world, with the comfort of knowing their dads are right beside them.

Inspired by words spoken between Gianna Floyd with President Biden, Daddy Speaks Love explores the special bond a father and child share.

Daddy Speaks Love will be released in January 2022. Ages 3-8. @nancyrosep @penguinkids

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Conscious Kid on September 07, 2021 tagging @harperkids, @artsyebby, and @ashleyfranklinwrites. May be a cartoon of 1 person, child and text that says 'Better Together, Binderella A Big Sister Fairy Tale from the creators of Not Quite Snow White Ashley Franklin Ebony Glenn'.

node.text:
Between 2009 and 2018, sociologist Charu Uppal asked girls of different races between the ages of 8-15 to draw a princess. Nearly every drawing depicted a white princess. Some of the girls of color explained that they could not be a princess because their skin was too dark and they were not beautiful enough. Their imaginations of what a princess looked like, and who could be one, was limited by how they had seen princesses depicted.

That's one of the reasons we loved the 2019 picture book Not Quite Snow White. It features a character named Tameika who loves to act, dance, and sing, and wants to audition for the role of Snow White in her school's musical. The other kids say she's "not quite" right to play the role ("she's too chubby...and she's too brown"). Tameika, however, knows she's perfect just the way she is and is just right for the role. She gets the part and shines as Snow White, making way for a more inclusive and body positive model of what a princess can be and look like.

The beloved character Tameika is back as Cinderella, in the follow up book from @ashleyfranklinwrites and @artsyebby. Better Together, Cinderella: A Big Sister Fairy Tale (released today) features another fairy tale twist, only this time, Tameika is navigating new siblings and all the challenges and joys that can bring:

Tameika can’t seem to do anything right for her new twin siblings and struggles to find her place when they steal her spotlight. Luckily, she and her family are attending the community family ball. Tameika is sure a ball will make the perfect set to prove that she can be the best big sister ever. But what if Tameika is wrong? With some help from her beloved Uncle Derrick, this princess learns that a growing family is always better together! She also learns that the best way to be a good sibling is to just be yourself. 

Better Together, Cinderella is out and available now from @harperkids. Ages 4-8.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021 tagging @nancyrosep, @penguinkids, @jacqueline_woodson, and @e.b._lewis. May be an image of outdoors and text.

node.text:
This unforgettable book offers a valuable lesson on the impact of excluding peers and classmates based on how much money they have, or what they wear or possess. It doesn’t have a happy ending where the kids are able to make amends after realizing the harm they have done. They don’t get that chance, but it gives us as readers a chance to consider the impact of our actions, even the smallest ones, on those around us—and what kind of ripples we send out into the world.

Chloe and her friends won't play with the new girl, Maya. Every time Maya tries to join Chloe and her friends, they reject her. Eventually Maya stops coming to school. When Chloe's teacher gives a lesson about how even small acts of kindness can change the world, Chloe is stung by the lost opportunity for friendship, and thinks about how much better it could have been if she'd shown a little kindness toward Maya.

“At some point in our lives, we are all unkind. At some point, we are all treated unkindly. I wanted to understand this more. I think too often we believe we’ll have a second chance at kindness – and sometimes we don’t. I do believe, as Chloe’s teacher, Ms. Albert, says, that everything we do goes out, like a ripple into the world. I wrote this because I believe in kindness.” —Author Jacqueline Woodson

Written by @jacqueline_woodson and illustrated by @e.b._lewis, this book will resonate with readers long after they've put it down. Ages 5-8. @nancyrosep @penguinkids 

Have you read this one?

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'One morning as we settled into our seats, the classroom door opened and the principal came in. She had a girl with her, and she said to us, This is Maya. Maya looked down at the floor. I think I heard her whisper Hello. We all stared at her. Her coat was open and the clothes beneath it looked old and ragged. Her shoes were spring shoes, not meant for the snow. them had broken. A strap on one'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Our teacher, Ms. Albert, said, Say good morning to our new student. But most of us were silent. The only empty seat was next to me That's where our teacher put Maya. And on that first day, Maya turned to me and smiled. But I didn't smile back. I moved my chair, myself and my books a little farther away from her. When she looked my way, I turned to the window and stared out at the snow. And every day after that, when Maya came into the classroom, looked away and didn't mile eback.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'The weeks passed. Every day, we whispered about Maya, laughing at her clothes, her shoes, the strange food she brought for lunch. Some days, Maya held out her hand to show us what she had brought to school- a deck of cards, pick up sticks, a small tattered doll. Whenever she asked us to play, we said no.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I have a new name for her, Kendra whispered. Never New. Everything she has came from a secondhand store. We all laughed. Maya stood by the fence. She was holding a jump rope but did not come over to us to ask if we wanted to play. After a while, she folded it double, rolled the ends around each hand and started jumping. She jumped around the whole school yard without stopping. She didn't look up once. Just jumped jumped, jumped.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The next day, Maya's seat was empty. In class that morning, we were talking about kindness. Ms. Albert had brought a big bowl into class and filled it with water. We all gathered around her desk and watched her drop a small stone into it. Tiny waves rippled out, away from the stone. This is what kindness does, Ms. Albert said. Each little thing we do goes out, like a ripple, into the world.'.
Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be art.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Then Ms. Albert let us each drop the stone in as we told her what kind things we had done. Joseph had held the door for his grandmother. Kendra helped change her baby brother's diaper. Even mean old Andrew had done something. I carried Teacher's books up the stairs, he said. And Ms. Albert said it was true. I stood there, holding Ms. Albert's rock in my hand, silent. Even small things count, Ms Albert said gently. But I couldn't think of anything and passed the stone on.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Maya didn't come to school the next day. Or the day after that. Each morning, I walked to school slowly, hoping this would be the day Maya returned and she' look at me and smile. I promised myself this would be the day I smiled back. Each kindness, Ms. Albert had said, makes the whole world a little bit better.'.

Photo by The Conscious Kid on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'That afternoon, I walked home alone. When I reached the pond, my throat filled with all the things I wished I would have said to Maya. Each kindness I had never shown. I threw small stones into it, over and over. Out and away. Watching the way the water rippled out and away. Like each kindness done and not done. Like every girl somewhere- holding a small gift out to someone and that someone turning away from it.'.

node.text:
Today the cover was revealed for @jacqueline_woodson and @rafael_l61’s highly anticipated companion to their beloved book, The Day You Begin. 

The Year We Learned to Fly illuminates the power in each of us to face challenges with confidence. 

On a dreary, stuck-inside kind of day, a brother and sister heed their grandmother’s advice: “Use those beautiful and brilliant minds of yours. Lift your arms, close your eyes, take a deep breath, and believe in a thing. Somebody somewhere at some point was just as bored you are now.” And before they know it, their imaginations lift them up and out of their boredom. Then, on a day full of quarrels, it’s time for a trip outside their minds again, and they are able to leave their anger behind. This precious skill, their grandmother tells them, harkens back to the days long before they were born, when their ancestors showed the world the strength and resilience of their beautiful and brilliant minds. Jacqueline Woodson’s lyrical text and Rafael Lopez’s dazzling art celebrate the extraordinary ability to imagine a better world.

The Year We Learned to Fly will be released in January 2022. Ages 4-8. @nancyrosep @penguinkids

node.text:
Today is the release day for @kingjames debut middle grade novel with Andrea Williams! It’s an inspiring, original story with heart that spotlights the positive impact of after-school programs and the many relatable challenges so many young kids face. 

Jayden Carr has been training all summer to be ready for Hoop Group—the free afterschool basketball program where his hero, NBA superstar Kendrick King, got his start. But when his beloved coach tells him there’s not going to be a Hoop Group this year, Jayden is heartbroken.

And he’s not the only one. Coach Beck’s daughter, Tamika, was planning to be the first girl ever to start for the squad. Chris King, Kendrick’s only nephew, spent the summer bragging that his uncle was coming home just to watch him play. For Anthony Pierson, Hoop Group was supposed to be his way out of trouble. And for Dexter Donyel, all 4’6” of him, Hoop Group was his chance to finally be part of a team, instead of just watching from the stands.

For each kid, Hoop Group was more than just a chance to ball; it was an escape, a dream, a family. Now their prospects seem all but impossible—but then the world hasn’t met Jayden, Tamika, Chris, Anthony, and Dex before. Determined to have their shot, the five new friends scrap, hustle, fight, and play hard to save their season to prove that sometimes a chance is all it takes. The first step to winning is getting out on the court.

This book is available now at the link in our Stories. Ages 8-12. @harperkids

node.text:
The Conscious Kid is honored to be partnered with @pjlibrary to share Jewish voices and stories. Providing early education about Jewish contributions, history and culture is an essential component of affirming Jewish identity and countering antisemitism. 

In celebration of Rosh Hashanah, PJ Library has curated a list of their favorite children’s books about the Jewish New Year. Rosh Hashanah is the first of the two fall High Holidays. The other is Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement. 

Rosh Hashanah is often referred to as the birthday of the world. It’s a time to reflect, sing, pray, gather with loved ones and, of course, eat delicious apple treats and round challah. This year it will begin in the evening on Monday, September 6, 2021 and end in the evening on Wednesday, September 8, 2021.

The books in the following list make a wonderful introduction to the High Holidays. The last two titles aren’t about the Jewish holidays per se, but they’re both great stories to help young children learn the value of saying “I’m sorry” and making amends. This full list, along with book descriptions and suggested age ranges, is available under the Book List section of our website. 

For additional titles, please see the PJ Library free digital guide for families, available at pjlibrary.org/rosh-hashanah.

🎨: @sophia_vincent_guy

node.text:
“When I was 12, after I hit puberty, I started wearing hijab every day. Before then, my mother would have me wear hijab on special occasions and to school on the days when I didn’t have gym. Having my friends, classmates, and teachers see me wearing hijab a few times a week made the transition to wearing it everyday easier. Still, and even though my parents did a great job preparing me spiritually and physically for covering my hair, I faced bullying from classmates because of the way I showed my faith. I clearly remember one boy in middle school asking me why I was wearing “that tablecloth on my head.” It was at that time, in middle school, that I realized my faith had the power to change how people treated me and that I may be “othered”—all because of my hijab. You wouldn’t think that a simple head-scarf could cause such commotion, but throughout my childhood, adolescence, and adulthood, it has. I wanted to tell this story so that children who look like me could see themselves in a picture book—a story of family, love, and faith. So that they can see two sisters taking pride in hijab, & see that the parts of ourselves that might make us appear “different” are worth celebrating. So that children of color, Muslims, and those who are both (like me) know they aren’t alone & that there are many out there who share our experience. Finally, I want to say it loud and proud. My hijab is part of me—it’s a testament to my faith and love of Allah. It’s a tradition I share enthusiastically with my mother & sisters. My hijab is beautiful. To the young girls out there reading this story who are hijabis: So is yours.”
—Author and Olympic Gold Medalist Ibtihaj Muhammad
✨
With her new backpack and light-up shoes, Faizah knows the first day of school is going to be special. It's the start of a brand new year & her older sister Asiya's first day of hijab. But not everyone sees hijab as beautiful, and in the face of hurtful, confusing words, Faizah will find new ways to be strong.

This beautiful, heart-warming book is an essential addition to classroom libraries and to kick off the school year. Written by @ibtihajmuhammad @skalibooks, illustrated by @metahatem. Ages 4-8.

node.text:
"I wrote [Your Name is A Song] in hopes of changing the conversation about whose names are worthy of being pronounced correctly and respected. It's sad that there are adults today who think it's fine to diminish the names of others. I continue to say that when we accept the diminishing of the things that make up a person's identity, we also open the door to diminishing that person's humanity. Let's not accept it. Let's push back and make them say (or sing) our names." — @authorjamilah 

Your Name Is A Song addresses the common microaggression of people mispronouncing names.

This book is an important counter-narrative that encourages kids to be proud of their names, which of course are not just names, but extensions of our families, histories, and identities. It also pushes back against ideas and norms that kids need to change anything about themselves to fit in or exist in a certain way. 

It engages this issue from the perspective of a child on the first day of school whose own name is being mispronounced. She doesn't want to go back to school because no one, not even her teacher, can say her name correctly. 

“She tried. It got stuck in her mouth.”

In response, the girl's mother teaches her about the musicality of African, Asian, Black American, Latinx, and Middle Eastern names on their lyrical walk home through the city. 

Empowered by this newfound understanding, the young girl is ready to return the next day to share her knowledge with her class. Your Name is a Song is a celebration to remind all of us about the beauty, history, and magic behind names. 

It’s a perfect book to kick off the school year and underscore the importance of honoring each other’s names and identities, and not being afraid to be and show up as ourselves.

Written by @authorjamilah, illustrated by @lupencita. Ages 4-8.
